Award.AwardTitle: Direct Measurement of the role of Confinement and Chemistry on Local Physical and Mechanical Properties of Polymers

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The research objective of this award is to utilize techniques based on two different physics to investigate the thermal and mechanical properties of polymers near interfaces. In one case, nanoscale mechanical indentation is performed by measuring the force required to push small tips into the sample either from the top or side surfaces. In the second case, spectroscopy on embedded fluorescent probes measures the change in light emitted from the sample at different temperatures. These techniques are complimentary and orthogonal and both analyses can be performed on the same physical samples. Current literature reveals that substrate stiffness may play an important role in the effects on the confined polymer. After synchronization of the measurement techniques, we will investigate the mechanical interphase on a variety of substrates with different stiffness. This study will encompass rubbery substrates through high modulus silicon wafers. The effect of differences in polymer-substrate chemical interactions will also be investigated.

Nanostructured polymers are important components of a variety of important systems, including lightweight structural materials, biomedical devices, and energy storage. Unfortunately, the unknown mechanical properties of confined polymers leads to uncertainty in design of novel devices and applications. Accurate assessment of interfacial polymer properties will allow for a more robust design space and tailoring of material properties to a higher degree. The proposed research will also serve as an excellent training platform for graduate students and postdoctoral fellows in the critical frontier of structure-based material design. Outreach to undergraduates, underrepresented groups and local middle-school students are included in the education plan, exposing larger societal groups to materials design principles and the technological development process. Students participating in this project will also have opportunities to collaborate with scientists at national labs (Argonne) and industries (Dupont and Boeing) in design projects.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Polymer nanocomposites have been investigated intensely in the past decade due to their exceptional properties and opportunities for multifunctional tailoring. A key impediment to understanding their physical properties is the existence of an interphase, a region where the nano-fillers interact with the polymer matrix and the properties of the local polymer is altered. While this interphase zone is a dominating factor in composite behavior, different approaches to measure properties of this regime show conflicting results. In particular, the modulus of confined polymers near interfaces has been reported both to increase and to decrease, and to have sizes ranging from a few nanometers to hundreds of nanometers for the same systems. Such discrepancies pose significant challenges in fundamental material physics.

This project has focused on exploring the nano-confinement effect and the mechanical properties of interfacial polymers via two different measurement techniques (AFM mechanical mapping and fluorescence probing). These techniques are complementary and orthogonal, in that the weaknesses of one are addressed by the other and the methods are non-interfering, allowing analysis of the same physical samples. A special sample was designed with two substrates sandwiching multi-layer polymer films to satisfy the need for both techniques (Figure 1). This configuration mimics the major interactions of natural composites, but in controlled conditions suitable for simpler analysis.

Our results on demonstrate for the first time a positive stiffness gradient in multiple polymer-substrate systems through two different measurement techniques on the same samples. The stiffness gradient varies from system to system: the extent and magnitude of stiffening for the interphase region for a poly-methylmethacrylate (PMMA) - silica system is higher than that of a polystyrene (PS) - silica system, which may be attributed to interfacial hydrogen bonding between ester units on PMMA side groups and hydroxyl groups on the substrate surface. Representative results for PS-silica are in Figure 2.

We also studied the influence of different types of chemical interactions/functional groups and surface topography in the mechanical properties of the interphase region. By varying the surface chemical interactions from stronger secondary bonding (hydroxyl bonding) to no interaction (silane coupling), a reduced extent of stiffening in the interphase region is observed. Additionally, changing the substrate from silica (glass) to a much softer polydimethylsiloxane (PDMS, rubber), a decreased interphase extent and modulus magnitude between PMMA and the substrate is observed. Thus, both the stiffness of the substrate and the chemical interactions between polymer and substrate play a role in the mechanical response of interphase. The quantitative results from the two methods differed, but the trends in all cases were consistent. The AFM data indicated modulus changes up to around 150nm from the substrate in all samples, whereas fluorescence method, which probes at the atomistic level, demonstrated a larger extent of the interphase in all cases.

A second series of samples was created where the distance between the substrates was decreased to 100nm in order to study the effect of interacting interphases from two substrates. Results presented an enhanced interphase modulus magnitude when the distance between two substrates was reduced below 160nm.

To assist in interpretation and analysis of the data, we pursued the study of interphase with the help of computational tools. We created a 3D model of the AFM test in finite element representation and simulated the effects of substrate, tip size, indentation depth, plasticity, and interphase. The results demonstrate an artificial increase of measured modulus in the AFM data when the probe tip is within 10 nm of the substrate, due to interaction of the stress field with the stiffer elastic substrate. The results provide a mechanism to remove this artifact from the data and validates interpretation of the data for further distances from the substrate.

The results from this project indicate that both AFM and Fluorescence are valuable tools of measuring local stiffness change of interphase of the modeled polymer nanocomposite system. The understanding of polymer physics afforded by this work helps to remove uncertainties currently plaguing design in small scale polymer constructs and will enable successful use in applications in lightweight structural materials, biomedical devices and energy storage.
